Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The WestRock CP, LLC  West Point Mill (West Point Mill) is committed to providing the optimum in employee and public safety and health.  It is the policy of West Point Mill to assure, so far as possible, that every employee has a safe and healthful place in which to work.  The West Point Mill is dedicated to providing the resources necessary to fulfill these commitments.  It is also the policy of the company to expect each employee, contract employee, and visitor to live up to the responsibility of following all safety rules and committing to safety.



It is West Point Mill policy to ensure adequate emergency response capabilities exist to handle an on-site emergency involving RMP-covered chemicals.  The facility maintains an emergency response plan that addresses how to respond in the event of chemical releases.  The key is prevention.  The West Point Mill executes this policy through employee training, equipment purchases and maintenance, and coordination with local emergency response agencies.



Facility Description



The West Point Mill is located along the northern bank of the Pamunkey River at 1901 Main Street, in West Point, Virginia.  The facility history began in 1913 with the construction of a pioneer mill at the head of the York River.  In 1914, Chesapeake Pulp & Paper Company began making pulp, which was sold to other mills.   St. Laurent Paper Products Corporation purchased the West Point Mill in 1997.  In 2001, Stone Container Corporation purchased the West Point Mill from St. Laurent Paper Products Corporation. Rock-Tenn Company purchased the company in 2011.



The West Point Mill handles chlorine dioxide (ClO2) and aqueous ammonia (NH3), which are chemicals listed in 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.  The Mill operates under the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) Code 2611 now recognized under the North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS

) Code 32211, one of nine highly hazardous SIC/NAICS codes.  In addition, these processes are subject to requirements under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  Therefore the processes are subject to RMP Program 3 requirements.



Chlorine dioxide is manufactured on site for use in the bleach plant.  It is produced by combining sodium chlorate (NaClO3), methanol (CH3OH), and sulfuric acid (H2SO4).  Sodium chlorate is reacted under certain conditions of acidity and temperature and with the addition of a reducing agent, chlorine dioxide is produced.  Mill production equipment can produce up to 25 tons per day of a 10 gram/liter chlorine dioxide solution, which is stored in three aboveground storage tanks.  These tanks have total capacities of 101,500 gallons, 126,900 gallons, and 144, 000 gallons.  



Ammonia (aqueous, 29.5%) is purchased for use in the facility wastewater treatment plant.  Ammonia is delivered to the site via tanker truck.  The ammonia is stored in a 15,600-gallon tank, which is the maximum intended inventory of aqueous ammonia.  

Pollution Prevention Program



The West Point Mill has a Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan, Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan, and an Emergency Action Plan that contains an Emergency Response Plan and Operations Manuals for Offloading Chemicals.  These plans outline the procedures in place at the mill to prevent pollution and respond to releases or emergencies.  Prevention measures include training, inspections, integrity testing and engineering controls.



Process Safety Information



Process Safety Information (PSI) relating to the covered processes is divided into three categories:  chemical hazards, process technology, and process equipment.  PSI relating to the hazards is included in material data safety sheets that are kept in readily-accessible locations for all employees.  PSI relating to the process technology is

generally indicated on process drawings, and is referenced in application Operating Procedures and Process Hazard Analyses.  PSI relating to process equipment is located in equipment files maintained by the Engineering and Maintenance Departments.



Process Hazard Analysis



Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) will be conducted on each covered process every five years, or when the process changes.  PHAs for both the chlorine dioxide and ammonia processes were last re-evaluated in January - February 2012.  PHAs are conducted by a team of knowledgeable individuals representing, at the minimum: operations, maintenance, engineering, and safety.  PHAs address the hazards of the process, identification of previous incidents that had a likely potential for a catastrophic release, engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards.



Operating Procedures



Written operating procedures are maintained by the Department responsible for the process.  Copies of the procedures are reviewed regularly by operations personnel, and are readily available on the facility Electronic Data Management System (EDMS). All Standard Operating Procedures and Policies relating to the facility Risk Management Program are available electronically on the EDMS.



Training



The West Point Mill provides on-the-job and/or classroom training to employees responsible for operating the covered processes.  The trainees must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the supervisor that they posses the skills and knowledge to perform the required duties prior to being assigned the responsibilities.  Hazard Communication and Chemical Training are provided to each applicable operations employee.



Mechanical Integrity



The West Point Mill maintains written instructions for inspection and testing of pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping, emergency shutdown systems, controls, alarms, and interlocks that are part of the covered processes.  Tests and inspections follow applicable and acceptable cod

es and standards.  Inspection and testing is performed at a frequency called for by the applicable codes and more often if test data indicates it is warranted.  Maintenance Procedures are housed in a database along with work orders.  Employees can generate work orders for repairs, inspection and testing.  Critical safety and environmental pieces of equipment are given top priority.



Management of Change



The West Point Mill has a management of change policy and guidance procedures to implement a review process when any component of the Risk Management Program is modified, replaced or upgraded beyond replacement in kind components or design.  Quality control procedures reside on an electronic database available to operators and are tied into interlock protection mechanisms built into the process so operators can not willingly make changes to quality control operating procedures without prior approval.



Pre-Startup Safety Review



The West Point Mill has a policy indicating the necessity to perform pre-startup safety reviews prior to implementing change in a covered system.  Documentation is in place to indicate a pre-startup safety review was completed prior startup of modified processes.



Compliance Audits



The West Point Mill last conducted a combined PSM/RMP audit in 2015 and conducts a compliance audit of the RMP program at the West Point Mill at least every three years.  The audits consist of a records review and evaluation of on-site conditions, which are performed by a third-party consulting companies with qualified auditors.  



Incident Investigation



Incident Investigations are conducted for incidents that result in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a covered chemical.  Investigation teams are comprised of pertinent representatives from the West Point Mill.  Procedures require investigations to be initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  Investigation reports contain at a minimum the date of incident, description of

the incident, investigation team members, factors contributing to the incident, and the recommended corrective action.  Supervisory personnel review open corrective action items on a regular basis to endure they receive a high priority for accomplishment.



Employee Participation



The West Point Mill actively encourages employee participation at all levels of development, implementation, and maintenance of the RMP program at the West Point Mill.



Hot Work Permit



The West Point Mill maintains an active Hot Work Program.  A permit system has been developed to cover fire protection, fire watch requirements, time frame for work to be conducted, equipment to be worked on, the responsible individual for the work, and signatures/approval of the supervisor, operating department, and shift safety watchman.  Hot Work permits are issued for all hot work conducted in RMP covered processes.



Contractors



Contract personnel at the West Point Mill provide service in supplementing the work force and in providing specialized expertise in servicing process components. Contractor safety performance is evaluated prior to commencing work in an RMP area, and are provided with applicable safety information and are notified of the hazards in the areas where they will be working at the West Point Mill.  



Five-Year Accident History



On February 20, 2015, an incident occurred in the bleach plant where an employee's exposure to a release of chlorine dioxide resulted in the employee receiving minor medical services (Plant nurse).  The amount of chlorine dioxide released was calculated to be less than 0.1 pounds; however, the RMP*eSubmit program would only allow whole numbers to be entered, so a value of one pound was used.  The West Point Mill has had no other releases of RMP-covered chemicals which resulted in on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage or known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

Emergency Response Program



The West Point Mill is considered to be a Non-Responding facility under 40 CFR Part 68.90.  The Mill maintains an emergency response plan, as well as two Facility Response Plans. The Fire Department and LEPC receive copies of the Mill's SARA 312 Hazardous Chemical Inventory every year.
